data.title: Places to Be(bop)
data.summary: A Historical Map Tour of the Jazz Music Scene

data.text: The Cotton Club, New York City, NY (1923 - 1940)

This historical nightclub was a venue for a highly aristocratic audience, who enjoyed the likes of Duke Ellington (pianist/composer), Louis Armstrong (trumpeter/vocalist), Fats Waller (pianist/composer), Cab Calloway (singer/bandleader/dancer), Fletcher Henderson (pianist/composer), Kenny Clarke (drummer/later bandleader) and tap-dancers such as Sammy Davis Jr (singer). It was located on 142nd Street and Lenox Avenue (1923–1936), then briefly in the midtown Theater District (1936–1940). The club existed during the eras of Prohibition and Jim Crow racial segregation.

data.title: Swing Session
data.description: Provided to YouTube by The Orchard Enterprises Swing Session · Duke Ellington And His Orchestra Duke Ellington At the Cotton Club ℗ 2010 Storyville Records Released on: 2010-10-01 Auto-generated by YouTube.
data.caption: Swing Session

data.text: The Village Vanguard, New York City, NY (1935 - Present)

The Village Vanguard is New York City's oldest jazz club. Early legendary performers included Sidney Bichet (sax, clarinet, composer), Mary Lou Williams (piano, composer), Roy Eldridge (trumpet) and Jimmy Hamilton (sax). The club later proved to be one of the greatest places for Bop: Miles, Mingus, Monk, the Modern Jazz Quartet (Milt Jackson on vibes, John Lewis on piano, Percy Heath on double bass and Connie Kay on drums), Art Blakey (drummer/bandleader), Keith Jarrett (pianist/later composer/arranger), Sonny Rollins (tenor sax), Bill Evans (piano, composer), Stan Getz (sax), Charlie Byrd (guitarist) and Anita O'Day (singer). John Coltrane made two notable recordings: the emotionally-intense "Live! at the Village Vanguard (1962)" and the exhilarating "Live at the Village Vanguard Again!" (1966). His band consisted of a musically-explosive list of musicians: Eric Dolphy (alto saxophonist/bass clarinetist/flautist), McCoy Tyner (pianist/composer), Elvin Jones (drummer), Jimmy Garrison (bassist) then later, Eastern-influenced Pharoah Sanders (saxophonist/composer) and Alice Coltrane (pianist/organist/harpist/vocalist).

data.text: Minton's Playhouse, NY (1938 - 1974)

Louis Armstrong (trumpeter/vocalist), Fats Waller (pianist/composer/entertainer), James P. Johnson (pianist/composer), and Earl Hines (pianist/bandleader) frequented this club, which played a significant role in the development of modern jazz. The club featured the electric guitarist from Benny Goodman's (clarinetist/bandleader) band, Charlie Christian, as well as all of the major players of the bebop movement, including Charlie Parker aka "Bird" (saxophonist/composer), Dizzy Gillespie (trumpeter/composer), Thelonious Monk (pianist/composer), Bud Powell (pianist/composer), Charlie Mingus (bassist/composer/later bandleader) and Eddie "Lockjaw" Davis (tenor saxophonist). Mingus remembered the auditioning he had to do to get up on stage: they asked if he could play 'Perdido' or 'Body and Soul.'[1]

data.text: 1. Enstice, Wayne; Rubin, Paul (1994). Jazz Spoken Here: Conversations with Twenty-Two Musicians. New York, NY: Da Capo Press.

The Onyx became a focal point for public jazz performances and hosted the likes of the virtuosic Art Tatum (pianist/composer), Bird, Dizzy, Roy Eldridge, Ben Webster (tenor saxophonist), Billie Holiday and Sarah Vaughan (singer).
Birdland, New York City, NY (1949 - 1965)

The long list of artists who performed at Birdland is truly awesome, including: Billie Holiday (singer), Bird, Dizzy, Bud Powell, Monk, Clifford Brown (trumpeter/composer), Count Basie (pianist/organist/composer), Lester Young (tenor saxophonist), Miles Davis (trumpeter/composer), John Coltrane (tenor saxophonist/composer), Mingus, Art Blakey (drummer/bandleader), Gerry Mulligan (baritone saxophonist/clarinetist/composer), Horace Silver (pianist/composer), Chet Baker (trumpeter/vocalist), Freddie Hubbard (trumpeter/later composer), George Benson (guitarist/later songwriter), Bill Evans (pianist/composer), Dave Brubeck (pianist/composer) and Lennie Tristano (pianist/composer). Count Basie and his Orchestra recorded Live from Birdland in the 1950s, and even recorded the famous Lullaby of Birdland there.

data.text: The Black Hawk, San Francisco, CA (1949 - 1963)

Notable musicians who appeared at this nightclub include Art Tatum (pianist/composer), the Dave Brubeck Quartet, Miles, Monk, Coltrane, Dizzy, Chet Baker, Vince Guaraldi (pianist/composer), Stan Getz, Cal Tjader (vibraphonist/drummer/composer), Mary Stallings (singer), Johnny Mathis (singer), Art Blakey, Shorty Rogers (trumpet/flugelhorn/arranger), Art Pepper (saxophonist/clarinetist), Art Farmer (trumpeter/flugelhorn), Gerry Mulligan, Ahmad Jamal (pianist/composer), Horace Parlan (pianist/composer), Russ Freeman (pianist/composer).

data.text: Cafe Bohemia, New York City, NY (1949 - 1960)

This was a restaurant, bar and stage since 1949. Guests included Bird, Miles, Coltrane, Mingus, Art Blakey’s original Jazz Messengers and the extraordinary Kenny Dorham (trumpeter/composer). Other artists included George Wallington (pianist/composer), Randy Weston (pianist/composer) and the blistering, virtuosic Cannonball Adderley (alto saxophonist).

data.caption: 'Jump Monk' from Charles Mingus' album, "Mingus at the Bohemia" (1955)

data.title: The Prophet (Set 4 / Live From Cafe Bohemia/1956)
data.caption: The Prophet (Set 4 / Live From Cafe Bohemia/1956)

data.text: Newport, RI (1954 - Present)

The first Newport Jazz Festival, known as the First Annual American Jazz Festival, was held on July 17th and July 18th, 1954 at the Newport Casino. The two day event featured academic panel discussions and live music performances from Billie Holiday, Ella Fitzgerald (singer), Lee Konitz (alto saxophonist), Eddie Condon (banjoist/guitarist/bandleader), Duke, Oscar Peterson (pianist/composer), Wes Montgomery (guitarist/composer), Grant Green (guitarist/composer) and avant-garde/free jazz revolutionaries Sun Ra (pianist/composer), Ornette Coleman (saxophonist/trumpeter/violinist/composer), Cecil Taylor (pianist/composer) and Rahsaan Roland Kirk (multi-instrumentalist/saxophonist/composer).

data.text: The Five Spot, New York City, NY (1956 - 1975)

With its low-key atmosphere and notorious bebop reputation, this club has attracted a host of jazz artists and writers: Monk, Coltrane, Dolphy, Charles McPherson (saxophonist/bandleader), Kenny Burrell (guitarist/composer), Pepper Adams (baritone saxophonist/composer), Jimmy Giuffre (clarinetist/saxophonist/composer) and George Russell (pianist/composer). This was where Ornette Coleman "began a 2 week residency that shook the jazz world." (http://in1959.blogspot.com/2009/11/ornette-coleman-and-battle-of-five-spot.html). Ornette recorded his groundbreaking record, "The Shape of Jazz to Come" in 1969. Free jazz was never explored in this way before since pianist Lennie Tristano's free-form explorations in the late 40s/early 50s.

data.caption: 'Fire Waltz' from Eric Dolphy's "At the Five Spot"

data.text: Massey Hall, Toronto, Canada (1894 - Present)

This large concert hall is known for its outstanding acoustics and is famous for attracting the world's leading celebrities. It's also where the famous Quintet played live in 1958 - Bird (here using a white plastic sax), Dizzy, Bud, Mingus, and Max Roach (drummer).

data.title: Salt Peanuts - Parker Gillespie Powell Mingus Roach
data.description: The Quintet - Jazz At Massey Hall Recorded live at Massey Hall, Toronto, Canada May 15, 1953
data.caption: Salt Peanuts - Parker Gillespie Powell Mingus Roach

data.text: The Monterey Jazz Festival, Monterey, CA (1958 - Present)

This annual festival started in 1958, was championed by Dave Brubeck and always featured an all-star lineup including Billie Holiday, Miles, Mingus, Monk, Dizzy, the Modern Jazz Quartet, J.J. Johnson (trombonist/composer), Ornette Coleman, the relaxing Bobby Hutcherson (vibraphonist/composer), the multi-dimensional pioneer Herbie Hancock (pianist/composer), the super-melodic Charles Lloyd (saxophonist/flutist/composer) and the riveting Gábor Szabó (guitarist/composer).

data.title: Forest Flower - Sunrise (Live@Monterey)
data.caption: Forest Flower - Sunrise (Live@Monterey)

data.text: The Van Gelder Studio, Englewood Cliffs, NJ (1959 - Present)

This studio was added to the National Register of Historic Places and for a good reason too. Many significant recordings were made here: from Monk, Miles, Mingus, Bobby Hutcherson, and Kenny Dorham to the lesser known hard bopper Elmo Hope (pianist/composer). The bitter-sweet Jackie McLean (alto saxophonist/composer), the masterful Chico Hamilton (drummer/bandleader), the Eastern-influenced Yusef Lateef (multi-instrumentalist/composer) and the electronically-progressive Chick Corea (pianist/composer).

data.caption: 'Afrodisia' from Kenny Dorham's "Afro-Cuban" (1955)

data.text: The Williamsburg Bridge, NY (1959-1962)

For three years, Sonny Rollins practiced on this bridge - woodshedding every single day away from his close neighbors and into the beautiful expanse of New York City. His practicing culminated in his aptly-named album, "The Bridge" (1969), one of jazz's greatest albums of all time.

data.title: The Bridge (Remastered)
data.caption: The Bridge (Remastered)

data.text: The Penthouse, Seattle, WA (1962 - 1968)
A jazz club remembered for performances by Cannonball Adderley, Miles, Coltrane, Bill Evans, The Montgomery Brothers (Wes, Buddy - pianist/vibraphonist, Monk - bass), Stan Getz, and Anita O’Day.

data.title: Cosmos (Live In Seattle / 1965)
data.caption: Cosmos (Live In Seattle / 1965)

data.text: The Plugged Nickel, Chicago, IL (1962 - 1971)

This tiny club was where the second great Miles Davis Quintet - Wayne Shorter (saxophonist/composer), Herbie Hancock, Ron Carter (bassist), and Tony Williams (drummer) - recorded some of their finest work. This was after Miles had hip surgery done due to sickle cell anemia and before he broke both legs in a 1972 automobile accident.

data.text: 6th Ave & 54th St, New York City, NY (late 1940s - 1972)

As a product of the jazz scene, I believe the avant-garde composer, Moondog, deserves a place here (at the end). He invented multiple instruments and creatively used elements of jazz, classical, and what would later become ambient music. From the late 1940s through the 1960s, Moondog lived as a street musician and poet in New York City, playing in midtown Manhattan, eventually settling on the corner of 53rd or 54th Street and Sixth Avenue in Manhattan.

data.caption: 'Dog Trot' from Moondog's "Sax Pax for a Sax" (1997)

data.text: The "Trout Mask Replica" house (1968 - 1969)

No story about jazz would be complete without mentioning Captain Beefheart (Don Van Vliet). 4295 Ensenada Drive, Woodland Hills is the address of the small, communal house where Captain Beefheart and His Magic Band rehearsed and recorded the majority of his revolutionary double album, "Trout Mask Replica". The album is heavy with avant-garde/free jazz, raw blues, and absurdist lyrical atmospheres. It is a truly surreal listening experience, considering that his band completed twenty instrumental tracks in a single six-hour recording session (the vocals were overdubbed later). Dissonance and experimentation run wild in every composition. And despite his radical/inaccessible approach to music, I would argue that Captain Beefheart laid the groundwork for the future of popular music, specifically the New Wave, punk and alternative/indie rock genres.  But without jazz, his music would cease to exist.

data.caption: 'Pachuco Cadaver' from Captain Beefheart's "Trout Mask replica (1969)
